article: "Guys, get out of the mud! How many times do I have to tell you?" I36 spilled out the words angrily. I felt myself recreating the37 _ words my parents had said to me so many times in the past, and I felt powerless to change my kids' actions. A(n)38 _ thought came to me, one that comes to most39 _ at some point:"Am I becoming my father?" We were on a short vacation, and my daughter and son were playing in the mud, splashing it with their boots, and40 _ the feeling. You know, one of those feelings that we adults are far too41 _ to enjoy anymore. It was the third and last day of our trip, and I'd been with the kids on a solo mission to northern Minnesota. My wife had stayed home to enjoy some42 _ time to rest. Taking care of kids alone was43 _ no easy task. And while we'd44 _ some great time on the trip, it didn't feel too great at the moment. I was45 _ with something many fathers did with: a sense of46 _ with my kids, and a feeling I should control their47 _ . My son turned around to me and said,"Dad, relax! It's OK!"I48 _ back at him, realizing he was right.49 _ , the mud could be washed off. No lives were in50 _ . The only51 _ here was my desire to control them. I wanted to thank him for his52 _ . It's useful to remember that our kids are not to be controlled. They should be guided and led, but not controlled. This desire to control can lead many fathers to an emotional53 _ with their kids. And while many fathers are clearly54 _ of this problem, they convince themselves that it can't be helped. The truth is that it can be helped, and fathers can55 _ the relationship they have with their kids.
